At 05:41 PM 4/20/02 -0600, you wrote:
>Ray Tayek wrote:
>
> >
> > >  The acceptance tests don't use the unit or integration tests. ...
> > this is good to know.
> >
> > >Could you give an example?
> >
> > i guess i am thinking about a hierarchy:
> >
> > unit (class) test for each class in a package
> > package test (can the classes in the package work together).
> > go up to the parent package and rinse til done.
> >
>
>I guess I don't always write a test per class.  If a few classes are 
>intended to be
>used together, I'll write a test communicating that intent and forego 
>class-level
>tests.  Often times I'll write a test for each class, as well.  It's a 
>judgment
>call.  Regardless, the tests are independent and can be run in any order.

ok

> >
> > the cactus testing is very dependent on many things. ...
>
>Each of these types of tests view the software from a different 
>perspective.  A
>test from one perspective shouldn't be dependent on a test from 
>another.  I might
>run a unit test every 5 minutes, an integration test every hour, and an 
>acceptance
>test once per day.
>
>Does that help?
